RT @UNICEF: You asked. We got you answers.

This #SaferInternetDay, we’ve brought together cyberbullying and child protection experts and t…
We want to create a safe and supportive community for everyone on Instagram. For even more tips, visit:

To give you more control over who can contact you on Instagram, there’s a new way to limit who can send you direct messages. The feature lets only the people you follow message you and add you to group threads.

We also want to help stop bullying before it happens. If someone writes a potentially offensive comment or caption, they’ll get a prompt saying it’s similar to content that’s been reported for bullying. We’ve found this can encourage people to reconsider what they’re posting.

ICYMI, we’ve also been rolling out more features to help prevent bullying. When you restrict an account, only they can see their comments on your posts. And they can’t see when you’ve read their direct messages or when you’re active on Instagram.

If your account’s been disabled, there’s a new way to appeal in the app. When you try to log in, you’ll see an option to “Request a Review.” Tap it and we’ll review your disabled account and potentially restore it. We'll roll out these features over the coming weeks.

You can also tap “More Options” for suggested actions – like muting, blocking or unfollowing accounts you’ve reported. And if you disagree with our decision on the content, you can request a review and we’ll take a second look.

Now when you report something that shouldn’t be on Instagram (like bullying or offensive content), you can get updates through Support Requests. It’s a new feature in the app that shows you the status of your reports. Go to “Settings”  –> “Support Requests.”
For #SaferInternetDay, we’re sharing some tips on how to stay safe on Instagram and take more control over your experience❤️

RT @GMA: EXCLUSIVE: Instagram works to combat bullying by using artificial intelligence and giving users options to change words deemed to…
This is an extension of our current feature that flags potentially bullying comments, and another step toward creating a safer environment on Instagram. 💖

Starting today, we’re rolling out a new feature that notifies people when their captions may be considered offensive, and gives them a chance to pause and reconsider their words before posting.

RT @jedfoundation: What you see posted by others is just one part of their story. A single post rarely reflects what is happening behind th…

Instagram partnered with the Jed Foundation (@jedfoundation) to create a toolkit addressing the Pressure to be Perfect, recognizing that what you see posted by others is just one part of their story. 

Learn more here:

Starting today, we’ll ask for your birthdate when creating an account, and in the coming weeks, we'll give you more control over who can message you.  
    
This will help us keep young people safer and enable more age-appropriate experiences. Learn more:
